s.text: (Apparently the publishers are trying to pass this book off to some buyers as neutral social history.)
(Apparently the publishers are trying to pass this book off to some buyers as neutral social history.)

In part, this may be because Frum is a bit of a snob; practically the only argument in the book that strikes Chatterbox as truly passionate is Frum's withering denunciation of the old-line northern Protestant sects for failing, in trying to make Christianity more "relevant," to attract new members.
As Frum points out in his book, almost nobody who actually lived through the 1970s (as opposed to today's teen-agers, who re-experience it as camp) have much regard for it:
